title: 107_s1528
content:
The Act is titled the "Rail Transportation Safety and Security Act". It provides assistance for passenger rail safety and security. The "Rail Transportation Safety and Security Act" allows the Secretary of Transportation to provide funding for rail transportation safety and security upgrades for Amtrak. This includes $515 million for systemwide security upgrades and $998 million for New York tunnel life safety projects and tunnel rehabilitation in Washington, D.C., and Baltimore, Maryland. Amtrak must submit a plan for security upgrades before receiving funding. The "Rail Transportation Safety and Security Act" authorizes funding for rail safety and security upgrades for Amtrak, including systemwide security upgrades and tunnel life safety projects. Amtrak must submit plans for upgrades before receiving funding. The DOT Inspector General will review fund expenditure to ensure consistency with funding documents. The Inspector General of the Department of Transportation will report any overlap between capital projects funded under the Act and those in Amtrak's 20-year capital plan within 60 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 3 amends Section 28101 of title 49, United States Code, by replacing "the rail carrier" with "any rail carrier." SEC. 4 addresses terrorist attacks against railroads. Section 1992 of title 18, United States Code is amended to address terrorist attacks against railroads, including actions such as wrecking, derailing, setting fire to, or disabling trains without permission and with intent to endanger safety. The amended Section 1992 of title 18, United States Code addresses terrorist attacks against railroads, including actions like setting fire to or undermining structures used by railroad carriers to derail or wreck trains. The amended Section 1992 of title 18, United States Code addresses terrorist attacks against railroads, including actions like damaging railroad signal systems, interfering with train operations, and committing acts intended to cause harm to railroad carrier employees or passengers. The amended Section 1992 of title 18, United States Code addresses terrorist acts against railroads, including releasing hazardous materials, conveying false information, and attempting or conspiring to commit such acts, with penalties of fines or imprisonment up to 20 years if committed within the United States on or against a railroad carrier engaged in interstate or foreign operations. The amended Section 1992 of title 18, United States Code addresses terrorist acts against railroads, with penalties including imprisonment for not less than 30 years or life for specific offenses involving high-level radioactive waste, passengers, or resulting in death. The offense involving firearms or dangerous weapons on a passenger train of a railroad carrier can result in a fine or imprisonment for up to 1 year. A person who possesses or causes to be present a firearm or dangerous weapon on a passenger train or in a passenger terminal facility of a railroad carrier, or attempts to do so, may face a fine or imprisonment for up to 5 years. If the act is committed on a railroad carrier engaged in interstate or foreign commerce, or involves crossing state lines to commit the act, the penalties may apply. A person who possesses or causes to be present a firearm or dangerous weapon on a passenger train or in a passenger terminal facility of a railroad carrier may face penalties as provided in sections 1111, 1112, and 1113. This does not apply to authorized officers, agents, or employees engaged in official duties related to transportation or law enforcement. Possession of firearms or dangerous weapons by authorized individuals, including off-duty officers, federal officials, members of the Armed Forces, and railroad police officers, is permitted under certain circumstances as authorized by law. Additionally, individuals transporting firearms on board a railroad passenger train in inaccessible baggage are exempt from restrictions. The prohibition against propelling objects at a train or its cars, with the intent to cause harm, carries a penalty of fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. This applies to acts committed against a railroad carrier involved in interstate or foreign commerce, or if the perpetrator crosses state lines to commit the offense. The section defines crimes involving dangerous devices, weapons, and destructive substances, with penalties of up to 20 years imprisonment for offenses resulting in death. The section defines crimes involving dangerous devices, weapons, and destructive substances, with penalties of up to 20 years imprisonment for offenses resulting in death. It excludes radioactive materials used for medical, industrial, research, or peaceful purposes. Definitions for terms like firearm, hazardous material, high-level radioactive waste, and railroad are also provided. A clerical amendment is made to the chapter analysis for chapter 97 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 5. RAIL TRANSPORTATION SECURITY RISK ASSESSMENT.

The Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with the rail industry and public safety officials, will assess security risks in rail transportation and develop recommendations for enhancing security in high-risk areas. A report will be submitted to Congress within 90 days, including proposals for Federal assistance to protect against criminal or terrorist acts targeting rail employees, passengers, shipments, or property. The report may be submitted in classified or redacted formats if deemed necessary.
